meta.meta: Roberts, T. R. (1986) Danionella translucida, a new genus and species of cyprinid fish from Burma, one of the smallest living vertebrates. Environmental Biology of Fishes 16(4): 231-241.

state.label: low number of its pectoral fin rays 15
9/9 instead of the otherwise invariable or almost invariable 10/9
absent
apparently absent on head and body (no canals or pores observed)
2 simple and 6 branched rays (last ray not divided to base)
large; origin near middle of body, with 2 simple and Xl-14 branched rays (last ray not divided to base)
moderately forked, simple principal rays (uppermost and lowermost principal ray of caudal lobes) of same thickness as branched principal rays (not greatly thickened as in some Rasbora)
with a midventral keel for its entire length and a middorsal keel extending for posterior half of its length
abdominal vertebrae much fewer than caudal; vertebrae 13-14+ 19-20= 32 or 33

anterior and posterior chambers widely separated (Fig. 2); in all other cyprinids examined the posterior chamber is much elongate and its anterior end is adjacent or very close to the anterior chamber of the swim bladder
stained with alizarin red
there is no indication of frontal or parietal bones
a large nasal or lacrimal bone is present
absent
very large, separated by a slender epiphyseal bar
premaxillae and maxillae are without ascending processes
(or ‘rocker’ element) is entirely absent

The four elements of the opercular series are all present and exhibit no unusual features, except that the preopercle is much smaller than in other cyprinids examined and bears no laterosensory canals
The basihyal is unusually expanded and broad anteriorly, with a straight anterior margin; in other cyprinids examined it is more or less uniformly slender
absent
evident only in branchial arch 2
with large scaphium and tripus; claustrum and intercalarium evidently absent
cartilaginous
without lateral process
with greatly enlarged ventromedial portion apparently attached to anterior chamber of swim bladder
very large
small, its distal end apparently attached to dorsal wall or anterior chamber of swim bladder
long

each half of pectoral girdle has the following elements: (1) supracleithrum, (2) cleithrum, (3) scapulocoracoid, (4) two proximal radials, and (5) a single distal radial (associated with the outermost pectoral fin ray)
The pectoral fin rays are 15 on both sides in 9 of the 10 cleared and stained specimens; one specimen has 16/1
ischiac portion small, without anterior or posterior processes
dorsal to articulation of pelvic fin rays with a knoblike ascending process
a single epural
three lower hypurals joined to ural centrum
Upper hypurals only three, presumably due to fusion of two hypurals 5 and 6 to form a single large triangular hypural
invariably 9/9 (observed in 10 cleared and stained specimens)

char.label: A cartilage connecting the fourth branchial arch to the fifth ceratobranchial
Only a single row of four pharyngeal teeth (tricuspid)
Innermost rays of pectoral and pelvic fins large and well developed (not minute and poorly developed or weakly staining as in Rasbora)
Basioccipital pharyngeal process is similar to that in other cyprinids
The supraoccipital, cartilaginous in Danionella, is raised above the rest of the cranium on slender bony struts

Large maxillo-mandibulary cartilage embedded in the maxillo-mandibulary ligament. The proximal end of this cartilage is attached to the ascending process of the dentary. When the dentary is depressed, the distal end of the maxillo-mandibulary cartilage moves upwards. None of the other cyprinids examined has a maxillo-mandibulary cartilage

The suspensorium consists of a single cartilaginous element or hyopalatine, incorporating the hyomandibula, quadrate, palatine, and possibly also the symplectic. The continuity of these elements as a single cartilaginous unit was confirmed by observing it with a Zeiss binocular microscope at magnifications of 20, 100 and 130x

Areas of strong mineralization, asindicated by intense staining with alizarin red, occur in portions of the hyomandibula articulating with the cranium and with the opercle, the entire palatoquadrate, and in two areas of the slender piece connecting the hyomandibula and palatoquadrate.

The infrapharyngobranchials of either side are evidently united to form an ‘infrapharyngobranchial plate’; the first three epibranchials are distinct from this plate, but epibranchial 4 is indistinguishably joined to it

A peculiar feature of the branchial arch is a small cartilage extending with its anterior end attached to the 4th branchial arch at the joint between epibranchial4 and ceratobranchial4 and its posterior end attached to the upper end of ceratobranchial 5. This element is labelled epibranchial 5? in my drawing. This identification is tentative and intended mainly to provide a label for this interesting feature
The pharyngeal teeth of Danionella have elongate slender pedicels; the tooth crown is laterally compressed and bears three cusps
Pelvic girdle with simple, slender anterior pelvic process meeting its opposite member at ventral midline of body
Posterior portion of each half of girdle widely separated
